_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Phase 4: Support and maintain
body:
The last phase in our methodology is the Support and Maintenance of Solutions: where we provide support that enables sustainable solutions to the project’s output.

 

What role can data play in this phase?

_items.text: To monitor the performance of the solution
To provide insight to inform similar future projects
To evaluate if there was an overspend

title: The common stages surrounding data use in projects
displayTitle: The common stages surrounding data use in projects
body: Regardless of the project lifecycle or workflow that is implemented there are a number of common stages to effectively integrating data into a project.

title: There are four phases to our methodology
body: At Arup we use a methodology that helps us approach our projects, and work with our clients. In the following section, we are going to cover the methodology we follow during our project life-cycle. And we will look at a case study to understand how this methodology integrates data to assess its use and fitness to solve our client’s concerns.

title: The common stages surrounding data use in projects
displayTitle: The common stages surrounding data use in projects
body: Regardless of the project lifecycle or workflow that is implemented there are a number of common stages to effectively integrating data into a project.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Stage 1: Ensure it is appropriate to use data
displayTitle: Stage 1: Ensure it is appropriate to use data
body:
Regardless of the stage of the project you are at. Before simply using data, you need to carefully consider if using data is appropriate, for example it might not be lawful to use data. Such questions might include:

  • Will data help solve the problem?
  • Does appropriate data exist or be collected?
  • Is the data reliable/from a reliable source?
  • Is the data biased or affected by targets?
  • Do domain experts think it should be used?
  • Are there any ethical or legal issues surrounding the collection, use and sharing of the data?
  • What are our responsibilities when using data as part of the project?

title: Working with data at ARUP
body:
Arup was founded on the belief that the built environment can change people’s lives for the better, and we can shape a better world. Every day, everywhere, we strive to meet this aim helping clients solve their most complex challenges by harnessing our diverse skills and constantly expanding what’s technically possible. 

To solve these challenges there may be many suitable approaches; The question is, how do we assess the one that is most appropriate? 

This course looks at how data can play a key role in not only assessing the most appropriate solutions, but also be part of the solution.

title: Data is not new
body:
We have always utilised data of some form within our work. Now more than ever, data is available, accessible, varied, and present in large volumes that we have to carefully consider how and when to use data to enhance our solutions. 
     
It is our skills and capability, coupled with our expertise, data, and the insight it generates that enables us to provide intelligent solutions.

title: 3 aspects
body: Image of key aspects - skills and capability, expertise, data and the insight

title: Component title
body: Picture of all 4 stages with "?" in the places where the review should be

title: Course overview
body:
There is a common data lifecycle; starting with data collection and ending with communicating outputs. Surrounding this is the challenge being solved, as defined by the client and scoped through the project methodology. 

In this module we will explore how to define the scope of work when we utilise data and briefly introduce the different stages of the data lifecycle that follow.

title: Stage 2: Data acquisition and management
body: Having established that it is appropriate and lawful to use data as part of a project, the next stage is to gather and prepare data ready for use.

_items.title: Establishing data requirements
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] ARUP will often source data from clients. When doing this it is critically important to carefully specify what data we require to solve the problem. We may also source data from multiple clients and it is important that the data is high quality, well structured and interoperable. Spending time and care on getting the right set of requirements saves a lot of time and effort later.

_items.title: Data acquisition and sources
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] ARUP already acquires data from a number of sources. For data we don’t hold already there are a number of acquisition techniques we use regularly and could be reused in your project.

_items.title: Data storage and management
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Once data is acquired, we need to store and manage it appropriately. At this point we must consider both our needs and responsibilities in order to make the best decision about how to store the data and what continual management processes are required to ensure we fulfil our obligations with that data.

_items.title: Cleaning and transforming data
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Unless data is collected specifically for the project it is unlikely the data will be a perfect fit. The process of cleaning and transforming data is used to ensure that the quality and usability of the data is maximised. This helps ensure that results are robust and reliable.

title: Phase 3: Design and build solution
body:
Phase 3 is the second iteration of the double diamond method. We follow the same pattern of divergent and convergent thinking, this time focusing on solutions that address a fully understood problem.

Many potential solutions might be investigated at this stage before the final one is proposed. Solutions might require a simple change in behaviour or the implementation of an existing system. Alternatively, a long complex project may require to install a whole new solution. Likewise, the output of this phase could be a simple solution brief or a large solution proposal.

title: Which of the following must be done between each phase?
displayTitle: Which of the following must be done between each phase?

_items.text: Review against original problem statement, goals and objectives
Collect data ready for the next phase

title: Our methodology
body: There are four key stages in our methodology, can you put them in order?

title: Stage 2: Discover and define requirements
body:
Once the motivation has been established and the project brief created, you enter the Discover and Define Requirements stage. This stage is the first iteration in what is called the ‘double diamond’ method.

Each diamond represents a process of divergent and convergent thinking; in the first instance this is used to Discover insight into the problem (divergent) and Define the area of focus (convergent). This phase is critically important to ensure that the actual problem has been identified. At the end of this phase the design brief is created. The design brief outlines the specifics of the problem and objectives to be met by any proposed solutions. 

Again this should be checked against the project brief to ensure that the two are aligned.

title: Phase 1: Establishing Motivation
body:
The initial stage in every project begins with the definition and scope of the project. In our methodology we define this stage as: ‘Establish Motivation’ where we establish our client’s motivation as well as our own to determine the right goals and objectives. At the end of this stage the project brief is created.

 

Which of the following should be contained in a design brief?

title: What would you do after collecting data?
displayTitle: What would you do after collecting data?

_items.text: Move to the next phase and start to design solutions
Investigate the reliability of third party data (i.e. that from the existing system)
_items.feedback:
That's right!

 

Before moving forwards or backwards in stages it may be necessary to check the reliability of collected data, especially that coming from third parties and existing systems.

In the case of the gallery, additional sensors were installed to verify the reading coming from the existing humidity control system. By comparing data from a new set of calibrated sensors to those already installed it was discovered that the sensors were faulty and not triggering the humidity control system at the right times.

_items.text: Go back and redefine the problem

title: Component title
body:
In 2018, ARUP was contracted by a large art gallery to help them investigate and overcome an apparent humidity problem that had the potential to damage the valuable art collection that was stored in the basement.

 

If you were the decision maker leading this project, what would you do first?

_items.text: Engineer a new humidity control systmem
_items.feedback: Although the client has approached us with a problem, we still need to establish the extent of the problem and scope the objectives and measures of success. This allows our experts to check the problem the client has identified is actually the problem. In the example of a gallery, maybe another source of humidity has been introduced that can simply be removed.

_items.text: Work with the client to scope the problem and set objectives
Gather data to analyse the cause of the problem
_items.feedback: Although the client has approached us with a problem, we still need to establish the extent of the problem and scope the objectives and measures of success. This allows our experts to check the problem the client has identified is actually the problem. In the example of a gallery, maybe another source of humidity has been introduced that can simply be removed.

title: Repeating stages
body:
The jump from one phase to another is another is not linear; we might need to iterate our solutions by jumping back to a previous stage. For example, the first discovery phase may result in an inconclusive design brief. In this case either more discovery may be required, or it might be necessary to go back a stage an re-evaluate the problem statement.

 

In all cases, it is better to go back rather than designing, building and delivering the wrong solution, which has the danger to cause us and our client high costs and damage.

title: Phase 4: Support and maintain
body:
The last phase in our methodology is the Support and Maintenance of Solutions: where we provide support that enables sustainable solutions to the project’s output.

 

What role can data play in this phase?

_items.text: To monitor the performance of the solution
To provide insight to inform similar future projects
To evaluate if there was an overspend

title: Stakeholder engagement
body:
The divergent-convergent thinking process is a learning journey. For a project to be a success, all stakeholders will likely need to be involved in this journey. Think of the width of the diamonds representing the number of stakeholders involved, both internally and externally at those two crucial phases.

 

At what point should stakeholders be able to engage with us?

_items.text: At the beginning to set goals and objectives
During the production reports and briefs

title: Stage 2: Data acquisition and management
body: Having established that it is appropriate and lawful to use data as part of a project, the next stage is to gather and prepare data ready for use.

_items.title: Establishing data requirements
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] ARUP will often source data from clients. When doing this it is critically important to carefully specify what data we require to solve the problem. We may also source data from multiple clients and it is important that the data is high quality, well structured and interoperable. Spending time and care on getting the right set of requirements saves a lot of time and effort later.

_items.title: Data acquisition and sources
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] ARUP already acquires data from a number of sources. For data we don’t hold already there are a number of acquisition techniques we use regularly and could be reused in your project.

_items.title: Data storage and management
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Once data is acquired, we need to store and manage it appropriately. At this point we must consider both our needs and responsibilities in order to make the best decision about how to store the data and what continual management processes are required to ensure we fulfil our obligations with that data.

_items.title: Cleaning and transforming data
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Unless data is collected specifically for the project it is unlikely the data will be a perfect fit. The process of cleaning and transforming data is used to ensure that the quality and usability of the data is maximised. This helps ensure that results are robust and reliable.

title: Stage 3: Data analysis and communication
body: With data acquired, stored and quality checked, the next stage is to analyse, validate and communicate insights found in the data.

_items.title: Exploratory data analysis
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is an approach used to understand and analyse the main characteristics of a dataset. Primarily EDA has two purposes (1) to check assumptions, completeness,  model fitting and hypothesis testing (2) to formulate hypotheses that could lead to new data collection and experiments.

_items.title: Deeper analysis, prediction and machine learning
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Exploratory data analysis will reveal the opportunity to perform deeper analysis using the data and even build models that predict potential outcomes. More complex techniques including machine learning can also help us process and build models based upon vast amounts of data.

_items.title: Validating results
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Regardless of how we analyse data or the model we build it is necessary to validate the results and clearly outline any limitations in the analysis.

_items.title: Communicating outputs
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] All of this analysis amounts to nothing if it isn’t effectively used in the decision making process. Using a compelling way to communicate the results, such as a carefully crafted visualisation or immersive experience can reassure our clients about the expertise that ARUP is able to bring to solutions facilities by data.

_items.title: Data collection points
_items.body:
Data can play a key role in all phases of our methodology. Does that mean that we only need one dataset to solve the problem? Probably not. Relying on one dataset can lead to the wrong conclusions; using data from a variety of sources will improve the quality and robustness of our solution.

Data can come from a number of sources. Some we may already have, some might come from the client or third parties and sometimes we might need to collect new data.

In our Gallery case study, the client  gave us access to data from the current humidity control system to analyse as part of the discovery phase. We also worked with the client to collect additional data about the usage of the gallery to help us identify any correlations between the high levels of humidity and aspects such as number of current visitors.

At the end of the Discovery phase, analysis of the data led to no conclusive design brief. The problem still wasn’t clear. No correlation was found between the humidity and any given condition.

_items.title: Finding the right solution
_items.body:
A set of faulty sensors was the entire cause of the humidity problem in the gallery.

A detailed discovery phase led to a quick and efficient design & build phase. The best solution also turned out to be the cheapest and least impact on the usage of the gallery.

Following the four phase methodology incentives the revision of insights and proposed solutions, avoiding jumping directly to an initial instinct which might have been the design of an entire new humidity control system.

_items.title: Obtaining data
_items.body:
As we have seen, the insight data provides help us deliver the right solution to our customers.

Let’s bust one myth straight away - we don’t all need to become expert programmers to make better use of data.

This remainder of this programme focuses on the common stages related to using data at ARUP and how these will enhance and complement your expertise.

title: Working with data at ARUP
body:
Arup was founded on the belief that the built environment can change people’s lives for the better, and shape a better world. Every day, everywhere, we strive to meet this aim helping clients solve their most complex challenges by harnessing our diverse skills and constantly expanding what’s technically possible.

To solve these challenges. there may be many options that are suitable to approach the right solution; The question is therefore, how do we assess the one that is most adequate?

We have always approached our work with data. Now more than ever, data is available, accessible, varied, and in large volumes that we have to consider how and when will data enhance our solutions.

It is our skills and capability, coupled with our expertise, data, and the insight it generates that we are able to provide intelligent solutions.

In this module we will explore how to define the scope of a project when we work with data, and introduce briefly what to expect in the following sections which cover in depth the different aspects of the data lifecycle.

title: Stage 1: Ensure it is appropriate to use data
displayTitle: Stage 1: Ensure it is appropriate to use data
body:
Regardless of the stage of the project you are at. Before simply using data, you need to carefully consider if using data is appropriate, for example it might not be lawful to use data. Such questions might include:

  • Will data help solve the problem?
  • Does appropriate data exist or be collected?
  • Is the data reliable/from a reliable source?
  • Is the data biased or affected by targets?
  • Do domain experts think it should be used?
  • Are there any ethical or legal issues surrounding the collection, use and sharing of the data?
  • What are our responsibilities when using data as part of the project?

title: Component title
body:
In 2018, ARUP was contracted by a large art gallery to help them investigate and overcome an apparent humidity problem that had the potential to damage the valuable art collection that was stored in the basement.

 

If you were the decision maker leading this project, what would you do first?

_items.text: Engineer a new humidity control systmem
_items.feedback: Although the client has approached us with a problem, we still need to establish the extent of the problem and scope the objectives and measures of success. This allows our experts to check the problem the client has identified is actually the problem. In the example of a gallery, maybe another source of humidity has been introduced that can simply be removed.

_items.text: Work with the client to scope the problem and set objectives
Gather data to analyse the cause of the problem
_items.feedback: Although the client has approached us with a problem, we still need to establish the extent of the problem and scope the objectives and measures of success. This allows our experts to check the problem the client has identified is actually the problem. In the example of a gallery, maybe another source of humidity has been introduced that can simply be removed.

title: Our methodology
body: Outline of a 4 phase approach with no labels

title: Summary
body:
ARUP is an engineering firm, and we are driven by helping our clients to come up with the most effective solution. The four phase methodology, facilitated by data, can help us deliver the right solutions to our clients.

ARUP is already data rich and we do lots with data. There is a huge opportunity to do more with data. We must also be able to recognise when data won't help, or worse, lead to the wrong solution.

The rest of this course focuses on how we work with data and will help you get the most from data in your projects.

title: Phase 2: Discover and define requirements
body:
Once the motivation has been established and the project brief created, you enter the Discover and Define Requirements phase. This phase is the first iteration in the double diamond method. Each diamond in this method represents a process of divergent and convergent thinking; in the first instance this is used to Discover insight into the problem (divergent) and Define the area of focus (convergent). This phase is critically important to ensure that the actual problem has been identified. At the end of this phase we create the design brief that displays what we have analysed so far.

This phase is similar to the diagnosis phase in the medical profession. The patient may have come in with chest pain, but the cause could have been caused by a trapped nerve in the back.

Our expertise at ARUP is critical in this phase to ensure that we diagnose the real cause of the problem and can focus on the right set of solutions.

 

What role can data play in the discover and define requirements phase?

_items.text: Keep the project on time and on budget
Monitor the success of the project

title: Stage 3: Data analysis and communication
body: With data acquired, stored and quality checked, the next stage is to analyse, validate and communicate insights found in the data.

_items.title: Exploratory data analysis
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is an approach used to understand and analyse the main characteristics of a dataset. Primarily EDA has two purposes (1) to check assumptions, completeness,  model fitting and hypothesis testing (2) to formulate hypotheses that could lead to new data collection and experiments.

_items.title: Deeper analysis, prediction and machine learning
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Exploratory data analysis will reveal the opportunity to perform deeper analysis using the data and even build models that predict potential outcomes. More complex techniques including machine learning can also help us process and build models based upon vast amounts of data.

_items.title: Validating results
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] Regardless of how we analyse data or the model we build it is necessary to validate the results and clearly outline any limitations in the analysis.

_items.title: Communicating outputs
_items.body: [TO BE FINALISED ONCE THE RELATED MODULE IS COMPLETE] All of this analysis amounts to nothing if it isn’t effectively used in the decision making process. Using a compelling way to communicate the results, such as a carefully crafted visualisation or immersive experience can reassure our clients about the expertise that ARUP is able to bring to solutions facilities by data.

title: Summary
body:
ARUP is an engineering firm, and we are driven by helping our clients to come up with the most effective solution. The four phase methodology, facilitated by data, can help us deliver the right solutions to our clients.

ARUP is already data rich and we do lots with data. There is a huge opportunity to do more with data. We must also be able to recognise when data won't help, or worse, lead to the wrong solution.

The rest of this course focuses on how we work with data and will help you get the most from data in your projects.

title: Can you put them in order?
displayTitle: Can you put them in order?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Each stage is equally important to inform the next. Often the first stage "Establishing the Motivation" is missed in order to get right into discovery. Typically this happens when it is presumed the goals and objectives are clear. However not every point of view might have been considered.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Each stage is equally important to inform the next. Often the first stage "Establishing the Motivation" is missed in order to get right into discovery. Typically this happens when it is presumed the goals and objectives are clear however not every point of view might have been considered.

A detailed discovery phase led to a quick and efficient design & build phase. The best solution also turned out to be the cheapest and least impact on the usage of the gallery.

_items.title: Obtaining data
_items.body:
As we have seen, the insight data provides help us deliver the right solution to our customers.

Let’s bust one myth straight away - we don’t all need to become expert programmers to make better use of data.

This remainder of this programme focuses on the common stages related to using data at ARUP and how these will enhance and complement your expertise.

title: How we work
body: At ARUP, we encourage the use of an expanded Double-Diamond methodology; a structured design approach to tackle challenges that required creative solutions. This  methodology helps us define our projects, and work with our clients to provide valued solutions that meet clients’ objectives. In the following section, we are going to cover the various parts of the methodology and examine a case study to understand how this methodology is implemented.

title: Completing the project brief
body: Which of the following should be contained in a project brief?
instruction: Select four answers and then click 'submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

This stage helps us scope the problem we will be addressing within the timeframe and budget we have available, as well as the resources and tools that we will need to be able to deliver the goals and objectives of the project. This is an important stage because the outcome will always have to meet the stakeholder’s expectations because we want to ensure we built sustainable relationships with our network. 

A detailed design brief is not appropriate because we have not yet discovered and defined the requirements and limitations of the resources and tools we have available.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

This stage helps us scope the problem we will be addressing within the timeframe and budget we have available, as well as the resources and tools that we will need to be able to deliver the goals and objectives of the project. This is an important stage because the outcome will always have to meet the stakeholder’s expectations because we want to ensure we built sustainable relationships with our network. 

A detailed design brief is not appropriate because we have not yet discovered and defined the requirements and limitations of the resources and tools we have available.

title: Stage 3: Design and build solution
body:
Stage 3 is the second iteration of the double diamond method. We follow the same pattern of divergent and convergent thinking as the previous stage, this time focusing on solutions that address the fully developed and well-understood problem. 

Many potential solutions might be investigated at this stage before the final one is proposed. Solutions could range from a simple change in behaviour or a differing implementation of an existing system. Alternatively, a long complex project may require a whole new solution to be developed. The output of this stage could therefore be a simple solution brief or a large solution proposal. 

The right solution is the one that achieves the goals and objectives set out in the project brief.

title: Q: What role can data play in the discover and define requirements stage?
body: What role can data play in the discover and define requirements stage?

_items.text: Keep the project on time and on budget
Monitor the success of the project

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data provides evidence. Collecting and analysing appropriate data is critical to evaluate if the problem identified is the right one, or if there is a problem in the first place! Once you start investigating, you may find the problem statement alters as more insight is gleaned.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data provides evidence. Collecting and analysing appropriate data is critical to evaluate if the problem identified is the right one, or if there is a problem in the first place! Once you start investigating, you may find the problem statement alters as more insight is gleaned.

title: Reacting to change
body:
Once you start investigating, you may find the problem statement alters as more insight is gleaned. This means the project brief will need to be rewritten.

Following this, what might it be necessary to do next?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Be prepared to have to repeat any stage of the methodology. Solving complex problems requires not only creative thinking, but also critical reflection. As well as being useful, data can be equally distracting and it is easy to pursue interesting findings that bear no relation to the problem being solved. Not every problem can be solved using data and not every problem requires data to solve. Equally, many problems can be informed by data, especially in an ever increasingly connected world.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Be prepared to have to repeat any stage of the methodology. Solving complex problems requires not only creative thinking, but also critical reflection. As well as being useful, data can be equally distracting and it is easy to pursue interesting findings that bear no relation to the problem being solved. Not every problem can be solved using data and not every problem requires data to solve. Equally, many problems can be informed by data, especially in an ever increasingly connected world.

title: Stage 4: Support and maintain
body: The last stage in our methodology is the Support and Maintenance of Solutions: where we provide ongoing support that enables sustainable solutions. This can take the form of offering technical support in interpreting errors or malfunctions and building previous solutions. Additionally, we might engage in mentoring and training our client’s staff to enable them to utilise the solutions and ensure we offer continuity in our service.

title: The role of data in stage 4
displayTitle: The role of data in stage 4
body: What role can data play in the Support and Maintenance stage?

_items.text: To monitor the performance of the solution
To provide insight to inform similar future projects
To evaluate if there was an overspend

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data provides evidence. Collecting and analysing appropriate data is critical to evaluate if the problem identified is the right one, or if there is a problem in the first place! Once you start investigating, you may find the problem statement alters as more insight is gleaned.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data provides evidence. Collecting and analysing appropriate data is critical to evaluate if the problem identified is the right one, or if there is a problem in the first place! Once you start investigating, you may find the problem statement alters as more insight is gleaned.

title: Transitioning between stages
body: Which of the following must be done between each stage?

_items.text: Review against original problem statement, goals and objectives
Collect data ready for the next stage

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data provides evidence. Collecting and analysing appropriate data is critical to evaluate if the problem identified is the right one, or if there is a problem in the first place! Once you start investigating, you may find the problem statement alters as more insight is gleaned.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data provides evidence. Collecting and analysing appropriate data is critical to evaluate if the problem identified is the right one, or if there is a problem in the first place! Once you start investigating, you may find the problem statement alters as more insight is gleaned.
